Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at the text from my stepmom: “Can you check in on your dad tonight? He’s been quiet lately.” I knew what she meant—he needed someone to talk to, someone to ask if he was really okay. I’d promised myself I’d be there for them, especially after everything we’d been through to become a family. But just as I was about to reply, my phone buzzed again. It was from the synagogue group chat: “We need one more for minyan at the funeral tonight. Can anyone come?” I knew how important it was to be there, to help the community say Kaddish for the deceased. My heart twisted. If I went to the synagogue, I’d miss the only time my dad might open up. If I stayed, I’d let down my community at a moment of need. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of both families—one by blood, one by faith—pressing down on me, and I didn’t know which way to turn.
